item.content:encoded: Top Ten Lies of the Second Presidential Debate http://t.co/2oE20ue8 via @BreitbartNews The Second Presidential Debate featured repeated claims by each candidate that the other was not telling the truth--as well as at least one claim of fact by the moderator that turned out to be false. There were even questionable claims by the audience itself. Here are the top ten worst lies told during the Second Debate: Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: breitbart.com

item.title: Mitt Romney Adviser On Lilly Ledbetter Act: 'He Was Opposed To It At The Time' [UPDATE]
item.description: Romney adviser Ed Gillespie on Lilly Ledbetter Act: "He was opposed to it at the time." http://t.co/PtZvGGZT (via @samsteinhp)
item.content:encoded: Romney adviser Ed Gillespie on Lilly Ledbetter Act: "He was opposed to it at the time." http://t.co/PtZvGGZT (via @samsteinhp) HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. -- Had Mitt Romney been president in 2009, he would not have signed the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act into law, a top adviser to the Republican nominee told The Huffington Post Tuesday night. Now that the law has been passed, Romney has no plans to get rid of it, that adviser, Ed Gillespie, added. Link - Trackbacks
item.dc:creator: huffingtonpost.com

item.content:encoded: Romney Adviser: Romney Would Have Opposed Lilly Ledbetter In 2009 http://t.co/X5Texcrb via @thinkprogress At Tuesday’s presidential debate, both candidates were confronted with a question about equal pay for women, who currently make 77 cents for every dollar earned by their male counterparts. item.description: Romney reverses contraception position under pressure from Obama http://t.co/nNO6asMT #FlipFlop
item.content:encoded: Romney reverses contraception position under pressure from Obama http://t.co/nNO6asMT #FlipFlop In response to a debate question about equal pay, President Barack Obama took the opportunity to criticize Mitt Romney's positions on contraception by pointing out that it is an economic issue for women. "You know, a major difference in this campaign is that Governor Romney feels comfortable having politicians in Washington decide the health care choices that women are making," Obama said.
